Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2021
Data: I have read the reviews and I see that some people hate these bulbs but I must say that these are the best bulbs that I have had. They are rock solid and they work exceptionally well with Alexa and our Amazon Home. The quality of the bulbs can't be beaten. Now, what are some of the downfalls of LIFX? Well as some have commented, getting the bulb to connect to wifi and subsequently Alexa is a little more involved than most light bulbs but to me, it wasn't crazy or insurmountable, and once connected, the connection is flawless and reliable. The thing is that you have to scan a QR code for each light and go through the setup process individually for each light which can seem like a hassle but it's really not (it's just not instant gratification right out of the box). To me, that's the biggest issue if you can even call it an issue. The lights are expensive but get what you pay for. They work great, the color range is incredible. I have tried other brands and nothing compares. I can tell Alexa to do virtually anything with those lights and it's done. There are no connectivity issues ...I mean none!!! If you can afford it....I would get these lights. I know you will be satisfied and I believe the value will be worth the cost. I'm not wealthy or have money to just through around on light bulbs but it is my belief that these will last me a long time with minimal upkeep and hassle.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2023
Data: Pros and Cons: Each bulb is individually addressable over WiFi so no hub is needed, although this means that large deployments can easily overwhelm lower-end networks and it also limits their top-notch iOS app to only a single phone. Their Apple HomeKit integration is so-so as it gives access to only a small subset of the full power of the bulbs but it does enable multi-user access to the entire network of bulbs, including remote access. Despite those limitations, and although they're less popular in the market, I still believe LIFX is the category leader: their bulbs are bright and their colors are truer and deeper and they support and integrate with other smart platforms.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
Data:
I'm guessing some of the negative reviews are written by boomers or people who are tech-illiterate. I purchased a single light and received it yesterday. Plugged it into my standing lamp, turned it on, downloaded the LIFX app (android), and began the setup process.
The setup was ridiculously easy and straightforward. It auto-recognized the light, I had to put in my wifi password, and 'bam' it's done. It simply can not be any easier than that.
Easy to control through the app. The colors look great. Love all the color configurations and the ability to change the brightness. You can really set the mood in your room. My favorite feature by far is the ability to schedule your lights. With the winter months nearly here and the sunrise happening later, I can schedule the light to begin to fade in to maximum brightness over the course of 10 minutes to help me wake up before the sun rises.
I should not that I haven't updated the firmware since everything works perfectly out of the box. Typically on devices such as this you don't want to update the firmware unless you have to.
My only pain point (4 stars) was the value for money. They are a little expensive. Not sure if I'm paying more for the tech or the brand but I was happy enough that I ordered the 4-pack today so set some more up in my room.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2023
Data:
I use a Linux desktop as my daily driver. This review and my rating of the LIFX light bulbs is mostly concerned with that... using them with Linux. I was pretty delighted to learn after installing them, I could ping them directly over wifi. You *can* use them with a cloud based home automation system, but my net connection is pretty flaky, so I *LOVE* that I can ping them directly.
I was able to find a node.js package that did most of the heavy lifting and provided a simple API to turn them on, turn them off and change their colour. I *think* it can also setup animations, but I'm not really into that. I saw a reference to a python package, but I don't do python anymore.
I was able to find the docs (they're not perfect, but they're good enough) so I'll probably add a Janet or Clojure package... cause... you know... lisp.
The don't seem to be the brightest bulbs I've seen, but they're good enough for my living room. You might be sad if you tried to light a 14' x 28' condo with just two bulbs. I would say go with 6 because blue and purple seemed to be dimmer than green and red. That might be a feature of human colour perception or maybe it's the LEDs in the bulb. But when I tried out my Commodore 64 colour scheme, the cyan was MUCH brighter than the blue.
I would love it if these things were a bit cheaper, but they're cheap enough that I bought a few. I rated "value for money" at four stars. I'm happy with the purchase and definitely don't feel like I was ripped off.
So... if you're a Linux person and you want to do coloured light bulbs like all your iProduct friends, these are great. If you grok node or bash, it's pretty straight forward to make them change color at a certain time of day, when your spouse emails you or the CI/CD pipeline stalls (again.)

I do not use Alexa or Google, I set them up in Apple HomeKit. The HomeKit integration is not seamless, but I believe that is due to limitations of the HomeKit app. So I don‚Äôt really bother with the HomeKit app; the LIFX app works really well and is a much better user-interface for this purpose. The customer service from LIFX is atrocious. It takes anywhere from 3-5 days to get a response to every email and the service techs apparently don't read the emails sent to them. The service tech I was dealing with, Felipe C., started by sending me instructions on how to repeat the exact same steps from the help topics on the site. So it had to move through the same steps even though I repeatedly told him I had tried them, only this time I had to do it over a period of weeks because I was continually waiting for responses from them.
The light still failed to connect even after multiple attempts so I asked for a warranty replacement. Felipe asked that I provide various pieces of information regarding the light, including my receipt of purchase, and the light's serial and lot numbers, which he claimed would be printed on the light bulb. Felipe's response was that I had not purchased a LIFX product and that they would not be able to warranty the light. Felipe of course was not able to articulate to me how this could have happened and seemingly did not care that it seems so far fetched.
I was already past the 30-day Amazon return window because it had taken so long to work through the customer service process but Felipe and LIFX did not care and thrust the whole situation back on Amazon to resolve.
